block.p: To the Editor: In deploring Alan Sokal's prank article in Social Text and our book, Jonathan Roughgarden and his students (letter, June 3) display a touching faith in the reasonableness of postmodern commentary on science.

The "critical inquiry" they admire uncritically too often does "defy common sense." Thirty pages of small-type notes make this clear in our book. Mr. Sokal's article makes it clearer still: The most absurd passages are direct quotations from would-be commentators on science -- Jacques Derrida, Jacques Lacan, Luce Irigaray -- who are nearly talismanic in the postmodernist subculture.

To the Editor: In deploring Alan Sokal's prank article in Social Text and our book, Jonathan Roughgarden and his students (letter, June 3) display a touching faith in the reasonableness of postmodern commentary on science.

The "critical inquiry" they admire uncritically too often does "defy common sense." Thirty pages of small-type notes make this clear in our book. Mr. Sokal's article makes it clearer still: The most absurd passages are direct quotations from would-be commentators on science -- Jacques Derrida, Jacques Lacan, Luce Irigaray -- who are nearly talismanic in the postmodernist subculture.

If the pretensions of postmodern "science critique" were cloaked in the political pieties of the right, Professor Roughgarden would have no qualms about rejecting them. His solicitude exemplifies the cul-de-sac into which even intelligent academics can be driven by inattentive idealism.
NORMAN LEVITT PAUL R. GROSS New Brunswick, N.J., June 3, 1996
The writers are, respectively, professor of mathematics at Rutgers and professor of biology, U. of Virginia.
